Token Game

The token game is the graphical representation of the basic Petri net execution rule, describing the following dependency between transitions, places and tokens:

  • A transition is enabled, if all of its input places have at least one token
  • An enabled transition can occur - it then removes one token from each input place and adds one token on each output place

Note that operator transitions, in particular XOR-split transitions and XOR-join transitions used in workflow nets have a different behaviour with respect to this occurrence rule.

Starting and stopping the Token Game

In order to start the token game, press the   button on the toolbar. The tokengame toolbar is launched for the net. You can not change the net if tokengame is enabled. The enabled transitions under the current marking are highlighted with a small green arrowhead. To stop the token game, just press the   button, the editor window background returns to its normal color and the net becomes editable again.

If there is initially at least one transition enabled, the user has to choose the next transition to occur by clicking on the associated control element within the net graph or in the drop-down menu of the tokengame toolbar. The following two situations can be distinguished:

  • Choosing a normal or AND transition to occur
  • Choosing an XOR transition to occur

 Much more functions for the tokengame are described on the tokengame toolbar page
